reviewText: Since I first saw it in the theater, De-Lovely has grown on me.  When I first saw it I might have given it only 2, maybe 3 stars.  I was dissatisfied mainly by the placement of a few musical numbers, namely "Be A Clown" and "Blow Gabriel Blow".  Granted, they both served a purpose in the narrative, but seemed completely out of place and strangely staged when I viewed the film.  On the DVD, I plan to skip past them.  What also displeased me was the way many numbers seemed unnatural in the contrived way in which they were placed in the film.  During "Swell Party", the partygoing chorus looks completely unnatural singing a song together, they seem uncomfortable.  I couldn't relax and get into what was onscreen, and any instance during which a viewer is removed from the action onscreen is dangerous because they might have a hard time getting back into it.  What brought me back, though, were the numbers performed by today's artists such as Elvis Costello, Sheryl Crow and Alanis Morisette.  I didn't think I'd like Alanis as much as I did, but she was charming.  And Costello blew me away, as did Crow.  Using modern performers to add a new dimension to the music was a stroke of genius.The heart of this film is the characters, the story, and the beautiful love songs of Cole Porter.  Ashley Judd is perfect as Linda Lee Porter, who pretends to not care that her husband can never love her as she loves him, never be a real husband to her.  Yet it's so clear she she suffers inside as time goes on.  Watch her face when, during a small party, a guest at the Porter household asks Cole what served as inspiration for a new song he just played.  She wants so badly for the answer to be "My wife" and is visibly crushed when she doesn't hear it, yet only the audience is aware of this, as she quickly puts on a happy face to her guests.  Another example of her longing is her simple, touching rendition of "True Love", during which it becomes evident to Cole that she wants a child as he sees her loving interaction with the daughter of their close friends.  Not only is she breathtakingly beautiful, she is breathtakingly real and so vulnerable even as she pretends to not be hurt by Cole's being unable to love her as a woman.Kevin Kline takes so many risks in this film, as Porter is portrayed as being at times selfish, overly self-indulgent, and absorbed in his own talent.  But what talent he had.  It is said that Irving Berlin would marvel at Porter's ability to whip up a tune seemingly out of nowhere, when he would labor over a tune for ages.  What this film does very well is walk the tightrope between showcasing Porter's undeniable genius and exposing him as being merely human.  Many biopics tend to idealize their subject, especially if the subject has such mythical stature as Porter.  This movie does not go that route, and that's a good thing.Yet this is still a love story, as it is clear that Cole loves Linda more deeply and with more feeling than anyone else in his life.  When, at the end of the movie, we are taken back to the two of them softly singing "In The Still Of The Night", we are reminded that at the end of the day, he always came back to her for the kind of love he really needed, the type which transcends the physical.  "Poignant" is the only word that comes to mind.Also, the palette against which this story plays is gorgeous, stylish and sumptuous.  The costumes, sets and surroundings are wonderful to look at and beautifully compliment the film's action.

reviewText: I'll admit up front that I watched this film knowing very little about Cole Porter.  He's someone I only heard about occasionally, and I was familiar with a few songs of his.  Since I generally enjoy "bio-pics", I'm willing to watch movies about real life people and if the film intrigues me enough, I'll seek out books to learn more about the person.This film has everything going for it and I give the filmmakers huge kudos for the creativity they used in bringing the life of Cole Porter to the screen.  I like how the movie was presented as a life review in the form of a stage musical, as we see the older Cole Porter being led through some of the memorable moments of his life by a figure named Gabe, who's supposed to be an angel.  The use of his music is brilliantly done and I loved his more peppy numbers.  The ballads, however, were not my favorite and tended to drag the film for me.  There were some boring moments throughout, and that's why this film, I believe could have been much better.My favorite scene is the Venetian masquerade ball, with Elvis Costello singing "Let's Misbehave!" while Cole Porter is dressed as a Roman Emperor and his wife Linda is Cleopatra.  The scene is a showstopper, very visual, interesting, humorous, and exceptionally well done.  The other parts of the film I like happen to correspond with the Cole Porter songs I actually love:  "Anything Goes" (which always reminds me of the opening scene in "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom", since that was the first time I ever heard that song), Robbie Williams singing "It's De-lovely" in his usual highly animated style, Alanis Morissette on "Let's Do It, Let's Fall In Love" (though I still prefer Eartha Kitt's version), and the brilliant final, "Blow, Gabriel Blow".  That song was a perfect ending for a movie and I love that Jonathan Pryce (as Gabe) says "never start a musical with a ballad, never end one with a ballad" before launching into that song.  Those peppy moments help keep this film from being a total waste of time, but the rest of the movie, most of it was a bit too slow and dragged, which is partly the fault of using some of Porter's ballads.  It affected the mood of the film, and maybe that was the point.  This film does give the impression of being a perfect bi-polar film...the "highs" are fantastic but the "lows" are devastatingly depressing.  Its a nice tribute to Cole Porter and worth seeing at least once.

reviewText: This is a movie about an uncommon love between, Cole Porter, an ingenious composer, and his wife, Linda Porter.  It's "a love story, of course.  Little unconventional, but honest."Linda Porter:  "You don't have to love me the same way that I love you Cole.  Just love me."I liked this movie more for what it had to say than for HOW it said it.  Cole Porter understood the importance of rhythm, swing, and genre.  This movie does not.  It is constantly out of rhythm in direction, acting, and format.  The movie editor does not understand the importance of timing between the actors' statements (but at least it's not as bad as the poor editing in Helen Hunt's "A Good Woman" - that film editor should have his scissors taken away).  And I've never mentioned hair and makeup, but they are awful, plastic, and fakey in this film.The screenwriter had many clever things to say, but I do not understand why he chose this plot format.  The story is told as a "This is Your Life", where the old Cole Porter is looking back, unable to interact with his past.  And the constant jumping out of time keeps the movie from generating emotional momentum and flow.  I think the screenplay would have been better in a straightforward narrative timeline.  The "out of time" POV of two old, wise crackin' men looking coyly backwards was far too "Muppets."  I'm rarely critical in these reviews, but the topics in the movie are of such value that I care that they were not portrayed more sensibly.  This movie felt more like a regional stage-play than a movie.Cole Porter:  "God, she was beautiful."Narrator:  "She could stop your heart."Cole Porter:  "No, start it."Cole's songs extol misbehavin' - where anything goes.  They ask what is the nature of love.  Some brilliant musicians sing Cole Porter's songs in this movie, including Alanis Morissette and Elvis Costello.  Even Sheryl Crow chose a song to sing (and for those of you keeping score at home:  When is Sheryl going to stop singing and focusing on the loves of her past?)Linda:  "I think it may be the most beautiful love song you've written yet."Cole: "There's quite a bit of you in it."Linda: "What do you think you'll call it."Cole: "I don't know.  Something about confusion."  (True, and funny)There was so much potential in this material, but the potential was missed.  And the sad, prolonged and cheesy last 30 minutes are an unfitting tribute to Cole's vibrant, honest music and Linda's clever, uncommon love.

reviewText: I learned long ago that we can only recognize in the world what already lives inside us.  The expectations and prejudices we carry as we experience art, including movies, can spoil the artist's perfection.  One of my daily mental exercises is to try to look at the world through eyes unencumbered by self.  Such advice would be well followed as you pop De-Lovely in the disc player.Forget your knowledge of Cole Porter, your own sexual preferences, and all of you that lives in your persona where judgement thrives.  Watch the movie with the slate of you wiped clean and you'll see the magical artistry of De-Lovely.All art is a relection of the artist's self, and De-Lovely is filled with musical, visual, and emotional art.  Facts, though necessary, can get in the way at times so I prefer a little interpretive artistic freedom by the artist.  Such is the case here concerning Cole Porter's life.The acting performances by the cast are exceptional.  Kevin Kline especially disappears into the role of Cole Porter.The sets and cinematography are rich and detailed.  One example of the cinematic art of the movie is Vivian Green's rendition of "Love for Sale."  The camera slowly circles a sensuous nightclub showing what is obviously several different nights, but the song is unbroken. I was surprised to learn the scene was not edited for the effect of extended time compressed into a single song.  Instead the scene was shot in one continuous take with the cast members changing clothes and set positions before the camera floated back to their moment.  The change of gowns by Vivian Green is particularly apparent.  That scene alone deserves an Academy Award.  Watch it and you'll know what I mean.The musical performances of Cole Porter's songs reflect the impact the composer had on each of the performers, and their expression of that impact adds depth to their talent.  Many of the songs are memorable when viewed from that perspective.Finally there is the love story of Linda and Cole Porter.  If you are a couple who measures your marriage in decades, still seeing the love in each other's eyes like you did the first time you met inspite of all the victories, challenges, and disappointments you've faced together, you'll understand the power of love the movie declares Linda and Cole shared.There are not too many movies I believe earn more than Amazon's five stars.  De-Lovely needs a five star multiplier.

reviewText: This utterly facinating and extremely well made film brought into sharp focus the lavish life of one of America's finest songwriters. "De-Lovely" is technically a musical I suppose, but did not seem necessarily so. It was a love story too but not in the way most people would suppose. Cole Porter's riches to riches life was punctuated by a heady cornucopia of sexual experience arguably of the bi-sexual kind. His personal background is likely the well-spring of his complex and  sometimes difficult to vocalize lyrics. I found close captioning to really come into its own while viewing this work. By reading the lyrics as being sung, I developed a new found appreciation for his choice of words and phrasing. Where did he come up with those words...and oh, the content! Starring Kevin Kline as Porter and the breathtakingly beautiful Ashley Judd as his devoted wife Linda were inspired casting choices. The two talented actors glowed with that all too rare dynamic known as on-screen chemistry. Most of us have heard it said at one time or another that "the rich are different". Maybe so. What I witnessed in just shy of two hours was a chemistry shared between two highly gifted actors that breathed a convincing life and an easy believability into an unconventional marital relationship. What Cole Porter gave America is a rich and timeless musical portfolio that will live on and on long after we pass from the scene. One can only guess if this legacy would have possible had Cole Porter not been so emotionally conflicted yet so deeply in love with the woman in his life till death did they part. This film featured some of the finest makeup work ever witnessed, transforming a young Cole Porter into an aging shadow of his former glory. Some of his finest songs were richly showcased featuring several contemporary vocalists, the period costuming was wonderful and the direction by Irwin Winkler was steady and crisp. The Porter's love story is the stuff of show business legend and for the obvious loving care and dedicated technical craft that worked its collective magic to translate their storied lives onto the silver screen I am truly grateful.

reviewText: De-Lovely has all of the makings of a great movie. It has a wonderful and engaging cast, especially Kevin Kline as the American composer and songwriter Cole Porter. Ashley Judd is ethereal as the long-suffering wife of Cole Porter, Linda Lee Porter. Cole Porter?s music?performed mostly by today?s musical contemporaries like Robbie Williams and Sheryl Crow?is still beautiful, catchy and witty. The period suits and dresses are aesthetically pleasing. With all those pluses, De-Lovely should have been an excellent and entertaining movie but it isn?t. It left with me with an empty and confused feeling.Cole Porter (1891-1964) married Linda Lee Porter (1883-1954) in 1919.  Linda was a wealthy divorcée, and several years older than Porter was when they wed. Porter was gay. Linda and Cole shared a mainly platonic marriage, which included separate bedrooms in their lush houses. The biopic De-Lovely inspires to be a celebration of their relationship, a love affair that is higher (and perhaps purer) than sex and sexual orientation. However, it doesn?t succeed.The movie never truly explains why Linda accepted this type of arrangement even though she knew from the start that Cole would rather sleep with men. Did she do it because she was lonely? Did she do it because they were great friends? Or did she do it because she needed a cover for her own sexual orientation? One never knows. In De-Lovely, Linda Lee knowingly marries a gay man yet balks (a lot!) when Cole has trysts with men. She encourages him to move to different parts of the world to work on his music in hopes that it will distract him from his extramarital affairs, and then becomes upset when it doesn?t. She even leaves him, only to come back when he is injured in a horseback riding accident.  It only appears in this movie that Linda stayed with Cole to be able to apply for martyrdom.One is motivated to watch the movie from beginning to end to see if the secrets of their relationship are ever revealed. They are not, and, in the end it, makes De-Lovely a very dissatisfying movie despite its wonderful characteristics.As earlier mentioned, Kevin Kline?s performance is sublime. The music, although performed with a certain amount of campiness, remains timeless. (Skip the De-Lovely soundtrack and check out the Ella Fitzgerald Sings Cole Porter or the Frank Sinatra Sings Cole Porter CDs.)

reviewText: There's a scene in "De-Lovely" in which Cole and Linda finish watching the first Cole Porter biopic, "Night and Day," and Cole remarks that if he can survive this movie, he can survive anything. I'm not certain the real Cole would have felt more positive toward "De-Lovely."Unlike "Night and Day," "De-Lovely" tries to be more honest in dealing with Cole's homosexuality and the problems Cole and his wife Linda must face as a result. I say the film tries to be more honest but doesn't succeed.  It's ironic that one of the movie's stars, Jonathan Pryce, himself starred in "Carrington," a movie that accomplished in this regard what "De-Lovely" fails to do.The best word to describe Cole's gay liaisons in "De-Lovely" would be coy. Both director Irwin Winkler and star Kevin Kline seem to be lacking any gay sensibilities whatsoever, which one might consider a necessity in dealing with any kind of honest depiction of Cole Porter, who was very much a gay man of his time.  Or was Winkler simply fearful of not offending any homophobes in the audience (who would not be going to see this movie anyway)?  Where there exists strong cinematic chemistry between Kevin Kline and Ashley Judd, as Cole's wife Linda, there is absolutely zero chemistry between Kevin Kline and any of his male lovers. Here's a typical example. One cleverly written scene involves Cole's tutoring of an actor, John Barrowman, to sing "Night and Day" properly. Cole explains that it is a song about obsession and proceeds to sing the song along with the actor.  Later on, Barrowman meets kline for a gay tryst in Central Park.  This "Night and Day" duet should have been rife with sexual tension between Cole and the actor, so that the later Central Park scene could be viewed as the pay-off.  Instead, there is no sexual tension whatsover, either from Kevin Kline or from the actor. Kline's scenes with a Russian dancer are also devoid of any glimmer of lust or passion.  A viewer is left with the peculiar sensation that as a homosexual, Cole is a dud and is simply going through the motions and that perhaps he is a latent heterosexual after all. (Having said this and thinking back, I realize now that the gay sexual tension in "In and Out" is coming from Tom Selleck and never from Kevin Kline.)Neither director Winkler or star Kline needed to be more graphic in any way regarding this (to secure the PG rating).  (There is nothing graphic, for example, in the movie "Carrington," which does accomplish this theme of a gay writer's relationship with a woman, alongside his attraction for other men.)Other problems with the film also seem to involve audience appeasement in some way. The choice to use modern orchestrations and today's vocalists, with their modern vocal styles mainly intact, was jarring and less than satisfying, except for Natalie Cole (who sings "Ev'ry Time You Say Goodbye") and Vivian Green (who sings "Love for Sale"), both of whom were wonderful. Why are the moviemakers assuming that a modern audience cannot appreciate styles of music from sixty or seventy years ago?Some other choices were questionable.  The use of Cole's songs were mainly inserted to highlight dramatic situations that might fit the lyrics, rather than when the songs were actually written.  The fantasy framework of using Jonathan Pryce as the angel Gabriel to set up the story of Cole's life with Linda was also a peculiar choice, which led to a finale of "Blow, Gabriel, Blow" (beautifully performed by Pryce, I might add) but which was obviously ripped off from Bob Fosse's "All That Jazz."  Far more jarring was the "Be a Clown" number, involving Kline, Peter Polycarpou as Louis B. Mayer, and entourage.  Since the other musical numbers are all in some type of realistic context, such fantasy inclusions seemed a bit out of place.Finally, Cole Porter was a social animal, whose friendships with noted personalities of the period -- Noel Coward, Gertrude Lawrence, Fred Astaire, Tallulah Bankhead, George Gershwin, Clifton Webb, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, etc. -- would have made for some swell parties indeed.  In "De-Lovely," only a few notable people appear -- such as Monty Wooley as a cruising buddy, Irving Berlin as a mentor, and Gerald Murphy and family as close friends. Mainly, a viewer has the feeling that Cole's life for the most part was centered around Linda alone, his muse, and that this is their love story to the exclusion of all else.Granted, there are enormous difficulties in creating a movie biography of Cole and his wife, and the attempt on Mr. Winkler's part is certainly admirable. Even if the end result is less than successful, the movie is worth seeing for several reasons -- to hear Cole's music in whatever form, and to watch Ashley Judd's nuanced performance, even though she is far better than her material.

reviewText: What we have here is a film based on but not limited to the adult life of Cole Porter. How to describe it? It's not a biopic nor is it a musical comedy. It resembles All That Jazz (1979) and Evita (1996) when combining fact with contrivance within a series of flashbacks to create dramatic impact. Various devices (e.g. hallucination and reminiscence) enable us to explore various components of Porter's life as well as the various relationships which he developed over a period of several decades. Kevin Kline brilliantly portrays Porter, with an able supporting cast headed by Ashley Judd (Linda Thomas Cole), Jonathan Pryce (Gabe), Kevin McNally (Gerald Murphy), Sandra Nelson (Sara Murphy), and Alan Corduner (Monty Woolley). I guess this could be called a Film Noir/Musical Review. Defining moments in Porter's adult life are coordinated with his greatest Broadway musicals which include Gay Divorcee, Anything Goes, and Kiss Me Kate, later adapted to the screen. As for his most popular songs, several of their titles suggest double meanings when we take into account Porter's bi-sexual love life. For example, "Let's Do It," "I've Got You Under My Skin," "You Do Something to Me," and "Anything Goes." Irwin Winkler pulls all of this together fairly well. Yes, the plot has its lumpy moments and, yes, the make-up isn't always effective (late in life, Kline's Porter resembles Charles Foster Kane) but the musical performances are highly entertaining and I especially appreciate the fact that Kline sings as ineptly as Porter did. I much prefer this version to Night and Day (1946) which Porter enjoyed because he was played by Cary Grant. On balance, De-Lovely is an enjoyable film and I resist the temptation to offer a pun on its title when selecting a title of my own for these brief remarks.
summary: Porter's Life as a Somewhat Dark Musical Reminiscence

reviewText: Delightful, delicious, whatever, Irwin Winkler's De-Lovely is frankly problematic, but still one of the freshest, most enjoyable experiences of the movie summer so far. Think of one of the underrated American actors, Kevin Kline, a beautiful actress at the top of her game (Ashley Judd), and throw in some of today's current musical stars (Alanis Morissette, Sheryl Crowe, Diana Krall, etc.-scenes which feel a little out of place). You get one of Irwin Winkler's best, although the filmmaker is really not a great talent. Even though I did like the imperfect and deeply flawed Life as a House, this one I prefer more-even though they are completely different.It is not the best musical of the century because I love Moulin Rouge!, but I think that I like it more than Chicago, just a little bit, in that it has something to say. It is an often profound biography and a dazzling musical at other times.De-Lovely is the story of Cole Porter, the famous American songwriter of musicals which eventually became films. Set in the 1920s, his life is depicted through random musical sequences as he meets his soon-to-be-wife Linda and very quickly sweeps her off of her feet. Their marriage is troubled because of Porter's bisexual tendencies and attraction to me ("He has an enormous appetite for life."), which is justified by him saying that he cannot find love in solely the opposite gender. It is never clear why Linda stays by his side for most of his life, but it is apparent by the end that they both really did love each other.This "musical" is brilliantly stylized, with some of the best cinematography this year. Shots wrap around characters, the color palette changes, and there are even black and white images. De-Lovely has the amazing (and lovely!) ability to appear very theatrical and stagy on the screen. It is a very classy film, and is also great, brassy fun. Critics have commented on how the love story feels underdeveloped, but my thoughts are that it is supposed to be that way. Their marriage was airless at times, and Cole often displayed little or no marriage in his wife. The film focused more on the marriage than the romance leading up to it, which I would like to have seen a little bit more of.There are only a few musical sequences that are not being witnessed through one of Porter's musically charged theater productions, and they seem a little bit out of place. They do not illuminate from the material with smoothness and ease, but they are still a joy to watch. There were two instances of dialogue that did not feel true to the characters, but they will be overlooked. The performances are fascinating, and Ashley Judd displays more talent than she ever has before. Kevin Kline is astonishing as Cole Porter, even though I do not predict Oscar nominations for either...at this point. The musical guests are fantastic, as usual, and Alanis Morissette is the best of the bunch in my opinion. Also, on a side note, the artistry and visual aspect of the film is stunning, and I hope for many Oscar nominations in the costume, art direction, makeup, and cinematography categories.I enjoyed this film endlessly despite minor problems, and would gladly see it again. It is a highly sophisticated, delightful (and de-lovely), and pleasing film. Yes it feels empty and stagy, but that is how musicals are supposed to be! Characters are often underdeveloped, and the music is completely random, but seriously entertaining. Overall, it is a movie musical that is, justly, a tribute to the musical.

reviewText: At one point Jay Cocks' script borders on the self-congratulatory when Cole and Linda are shown viewing the earlier biopic starring Cary Grant with obvious displeasure.  This remake, of course, is going to tell it like it is, and indeed the script of "De-Lovely" strains to account for the (frequently) flawed face of artistic genius.  Linda tells Cole that his music stems from his talent, not his behavior, whereas Cole tries to explain that it's all part of the same inseparable package:  without the excesses, the disloyalties, the self-indulgences he wouldn't be who he is--arguably America's greatest songwriter.  In the end, "De-Lovely" is self-descriptive: not a pretty picture--more Asbury Park than Granada, to paraphrase a Porter lyric.Perhaps today's audiences need more proof that he really was a great songwriter.  Or given the moral correctness of our times, perhaps audiences are incapable of empathizing with those given to self-indulgences. Or they may think they know all too well "the wages of sin."  Or perhaps the acting of Kline and Judd overwhelms the script's good intentions.  Indeed, they come across as two people who, as each is fully aware, ask too much of one another.  He gives her gifts, love, sporadic devotion; she gives him gifts, his vanity (i.e., useless legs), and undying devotion.  In the end, and in the still of the night, Linda's devotion cuts through the darkness--a flickering memory but all that Cole has left before the screen goes black.We believe the characters, their relationship, and their deep if unconventional love--perhaps too much.  The film becomes a frequently luminous and tuneful soap opera about a main character who is more pathetic than tragic, about a self-destructive songwriter who self-destructs for obvious reasons, but in a deliberate, slow, very sad and depressing manner.  Orson Welles had in essence a similar character and plot framework in "Citizen Kane," but he also had the directing "style" (which above all should be foremost in anything related to Cole Porter's music and life) and a "motivator" to make Kane's willful and self-ignorant destruction a mutually shared obsession, inviting us at every moment to become adventurer-detectives searching for the clues that will lead us to "Rosebud."By contrast, "De-Lovely" wallows in pain and misery for the last 30 minutes, insulting us with a momentary deus ex machina ("Blow, Gabriel, Blow"--the clumsy choreography and camera work are exceeded only by the execrable, cheesy musical arrangement), and then attempting to rescue everything with that flickering, potentially powerful, image that is the film's final moment.  Too little, too late--and too soon, moreover, after we've endured the spectacle of our subject reduced to a pay-for-play "John," a victim of blackmail (triply so, because Linda is included, as is their relationship and mutual trust).  The soundtrack plays "Love for Sale," but what we witness is a love that's far more than "slightly soiled."The project needed to be rethought.  Most of today's viewers are totally unsympathetic with the private lives of artists (one would think the writers would pay attention to politics) and, for that matter, unfamiliar with Porter's songs.  The film would have done a great service had it opened viewers' hearts and minds to the "obsessions" (an apt term used in the film) of others, the personal mind-images and different objects of desire that motivate the passions of the artist in ways that move us all.  (What's the gain in portraying Monty Wooley as a pimp?)  Or it would have done an equal service had it launched a whole new wave of interest in the music of Cole Porter.Sadly, it fails there, too, for reasons too numerous to mention.  As a musician, I have no answers for the film's complete re-harmonization if not rewriting of "Begin the Beguine."  (If such flagrant disregard of the man's music is acceptable, why should we accept the film's representation of Porter's life?)  Perhaps it's just as well the film bypasses Porter "essentials" like "I've Got You Under My Skin," "I Get a Kick Out of You," and "At Long Last Love."  And, of course, only Hollywood can be counted on to make a musical about American jazz musicians' favorite American composer with nary a measure of music that swings!  In short, musically this production is clueless about the heart of great American popular music.  The performances and arrangements in "De-Lovely" owe more to the late Victorian-era sounds of the British music hall than to the African-American musical forms that directly inspired Berlin, Gershwin, Arlen, even Kern and, indirectly at least, Cole Porter.This is a movie/DVD that few people will care too watch more than once.  If you count yourself in that number, and if you're wondering why someone would bother to make a movie about Cole Porter, pick up any recording by Sinatra and Nelson Riddle with "I've Got You Under My Skin" ("Songs for Swinging Lovers" is a good start) or "Night and Day."  If you tire of either song (virtually impossible), try the inspired, absolutely scintillating version of "In the Still of the Night" on the first disc of the recent "Sinatra-Vegas" box.  And if that's not enough, there's plenty more from the same source, or from Ella Fitzgerald on the "Cole Porter Songbook." Or listen to Mabel Mercer explaining how it (in Porter songs, love is frequently an "it" or "thing") was "Just One of Those Things," or to Dinah Washington actually selling it on "Love for Sale," or to Danny Kaye performing the pyrotechnical verbosity of "Let's Not Talk About Love," or to any singer who imparts to these timeless, immortal songs and lyrics the life that is theirs, allowing them to become the magnificent obsessions of yet another generation of listeners.[Why the 4-star rating?  Maybe I got the movie entirely wrong, and if I didn't, maybe the movie succeeded in creating sympathy for and interest in Cole Porter as well as the original, indigenous art form at which Cole excelled: the "American Popular Song," along with "The Great American Songbook," which owes so much of its brilliance to the contributions of his inarguable genius.  Musical composition--in verbal, cinematic, or musical language--is not a thumbs up, thumbs down proposition.  I'm frankly bummed by dismissals of Robert Altman's "Nashville" (my favorite movie), but I'll respect the opinion of any reviewer who took the time to screen the film and give it some serious thought.]
summary: Great acting, good intentions, wasted opportunities

reviewText: I've been avoiding writing a review of this film because I thought it just wasn't worth the time. Seeing the comments by others, though, I finally feel compelled to do so. In a sentence, what were they trying to do here? We were told from the trailers and the pre-release reviews that the movie (originally dubbed 'Just One of Those Things') would reveal the bi-sexual aspect of Cole Porter's private life. Ok- in today's society, that's acceptable, but making it the focal point for scenes, indeed the compass for our journey, obscured the character of this movie and ultimately its purpose. Was it supposed to be a musical or a fanatasy or a drama or what?To begin, having  Porter (Kevin Klein) looking backward from the end of his life could have been beneficial, but instead proved to be a needless and distracting device: presumably providing dreamlike, ethereal quality as he revisits the (supposed)benchmark events in his musical career, it added nothing to the film except confusion. Was it fantasy?The segues (if we can call them that) between scenes and/or points in Porter's life usually defied any sense of context as well. The viewer is pulled from one time sequence and location to another, almost without reference (the off-stage Porter actually could have assisted here but his comments are parenthetical, not explanatory)- was it drama?As expected, of course, there was plenty of playing and singing of Porter's compositions- but just because they were included doesn't mean they received a quality treatment.  Much can be said pro and con about having contemporary stars interpreting 'tween the wars classics, but the approach was a real detriment here. A number of the performers, especially Lara Fabian, Diane Krall, Robin Williams, and Natalie Cole, have proved their worth doing period pieces before (not so for Alanis Morisette and Sheryl Crowe- ugh!), but even the good efforts were wasted in this. They were sometimes used as an irrelevant introduction to a scene, but more often as thinly disguised, cheap levers to have the presence of a pop headliner grab (or keep) the viewer's attention. The effect was imbalance, which became even more disturbing when the songs and performances were relegated to the background. An exception was the finale that went to the other extreme, making such bombast that it was more reminiscent of a George M. Cohan review than a homage to the music of a gifted song writer - was it a musical?Overall, the real pity is that "De-Lovely" devotes little attention to the nature of the composer's genius. The story either minimizes or distorts that issue, if it explores it at all. Rather, we are constantly reminded of Porter's male and female affairs, as if that would suffice. To add insult to injury, the pace of the film moved like a funeral dirge.  Where there should have been excitement, there was boredom.  Where there should have been exhilaration, there was resignation. Criticism can certainly be aimed at the original "Night and Day" version, with Cary Grant in the lead role, for not being historically(sexually)accurate or being too melodramatic, but it sure beat the heck out of this. "De-Lovely" is simply a mess! Despite valiant contributions from Klein and Ashley Judd, who played Porter's wife, not much is worthy of praise. If the object was to do a better, more authentic job of capturing the essence of Cole Porter and his music, it failed miserably. Then again, it's not clear what its point was. The direction, editing and script were simply horrid. - Believe me, you won't miss a thing if you pass on this one.

reviewText: Irwin Winkler's "De-Lovely" spins a entertaining yarn in the form of a bio-pic about perhaps America's most Puckish musical prodigy, Cole Porter.  Played with a quiet dignity (a surprising choice, given the rambunctious tendencies of the real-life figure) by Master Kline, Porter remains a bit of an enigma throughout the entire film . . . but an enigma who can crank out the tunes.The not-so-tiny sub-genre of the musical bio-pic is dominated by Milos Forman's "Amadeus."  "De-Lovely" is not in the class of that masterwork, perhaps because nobody in the movie brings any degree of malice to it even remotely on par with F. Murray Abraham's craven spider, Salieri.Kline also does not rise to the level of Abraham's performance as narrator, either.  Where "Amadeus" has a straightforward narration by the older Salieri, "De-Lovely" chooses a different narration structure . . . the aged, wrinkled, dying Porter watches a dramatic reproduction of his life with a director/producer/angel/devil Gabriel (Jonathan Pryce).  The motivation for this appears to be either a demonstration of Porter's dissatisfaction with his own life, or with theatrical interpretations of his works -- at one point, the dying Porter grumps, "This is all wrong," as a scene plays out before him.The movie also presumes that the audience is already very familiar with Cole Porter and the music scene of the times.  Whiel there is a brief conflict about whether Porter should move to the youthful Hollywood from the aging New York Broadway scene, we really don't see any positioning of Porter within the musical pantheon -- his greatness is often commented on, but never really explained. (Again, "Amadeus" exceeds "De-Lovely" here, both when Salieri tells of Mozart's famous youthful mastery of music as well as the struggle between the composers for the Emperor's favor.)(Okay, okay, I know it's silly to keep comparing this movie to one other specific film, but I had high expectations for this movie and wanted to love it as much as I love "Amadeus" . . . and the cast and crew also appear to have a strong devotion to this material . . . so it's a bit tough when the movie doesn't quite live up to expectations.)The movie spends a great deal of time exploring, in delicate fashion, Cole Porter's homosexuality and his complex relationship with his adoring wife, Linda (played as a worldly realist by Ashley Judd in a solid, moving performance).  While we may never know how much Linda actually knew about her husband's "other interests," "De-Lovely" manages to play out its theories in believable terms, and Linda's seemingly incompatible tolerance and adoration of her husband doesn't seem too far-fetched.Perhaps most believably, "De-Lovely" does not make Porter into man hopelessly in love with Linda yet sexually drawn to other men.  Porter seems to regard her with reverence, awe, and appreciation, but Porter seems most at love with himself.  This is a good choice, as Porter definitely treats Linda most shabbily.  The movie handles this with discretion . . . an example comes when Linda arrives at the Porter's Hollywood mansion, walks into the back yard, and sees Cole happily surrounded by several of his "other interests," blissfully unaware of Linda's arrival.  Had he seen her, Cole undeniably would have treated her with his trademark charm and consideration, but she understands that Cole is never going to make much of an effort to seek her out.  All in all, Cole Porter comes across as the stereotypical spoiled genius, and this rings true.The music, of course, is top-notch -- it's Cole Porter, after all.  Quibble about the choices of the various modern stars singing Porter's tunes on the soundtrack, but they are still singing some of the best tunes ever jangled.All in all, "De-Lovely" is a movie that I wanted to love more than I actually fell in love with, and perhaps that's an appropriate reaction to Mr. Porter, too.  An enjoyable film that can round out the film library, but not a "must-have."  More of a "should-see."
summary: Kevin Kline and Cast Make Delightful Music Delightful!

reviewText: A new film version of the life of one of the most famous US American composers of the first half of the 20th century (together with George Gershwin and Irving Berlin) was probably inevitable, since the film biography "Night and Day" from 1946, with Cary Grant as protagonist, was somewhat too sugar-coated.This film does not make a secret of the fact that Porter was homosexual (or at least bisexual); it leaves nevertheless no doubt about the fact that his ever-changing affairs with men were mainly of erotic nature and that the only person who was really close to him in his life was his wife Linda. Whether this was actually so is of course questionable; but in any case, "De-Lovely" did not seem to me as if it was pretending to be a perfect biography but is mostly a homage to the variety and value of human feelings, the feelings Porter was so incredibly good at catching with his tunes.It is admirable how many different and always believable emotions Porter's songs know how to express; also, he was an enthusiastic lyricist, his opinion was that music and lyrics ought to be "as married". "Let's do it", "Begin the Beguine", "What is this Thing Called Love" or "Night and Day" are classical songs which probably everybody knows, even if they are no experts with this kind of music.The crew of famous and all very talented singers appearing in this film is legendary and an enormous asset, the CD became one of my all-time-favourites since I bought it right after having first watched the film. I don't see what it wrong with the way e.g. Alanis Morissette sings "Beguin the Beguine" (the melancholy arrangement is to me exactly what the song needs) or with Elvis Costello singing "Let's Misbehave" with typical verve and humour.The only minor point is the ending: it seems as if the director could not quite decide which scene was supposed to be the end scene, so that as a viewer you get irritated believing again and again that the film is ending only to see it continue once more; I found this somehow dissatisfying and unnecessary. But apart from that, a well-made and recommendable piece of work.

Of course, it isn't new for Hollywood to get it wrong--but the people involved in this film should know better-especially Kline.While some moments are indeed culled from reality (Cole Porter did lose the use of both his legs in a riding accident later in life and did have to be carried into the opening night of his musical KISS ME KATE on Broadway), some of the "liberties" Irwin Winkler and the screenwriter take with the facts are rather astonishing.Like another reviewer has mentioned, Cole Porter led a fantastic, fun-filled social life, surrounded by wonderful personalities like Elsa Maxwell (where was she in the film?), Monty Wooley (represented, but poorly), the African-American entertainer Bricktop, Noel Coward, and the Windsors.  Of course his parties would have been something else!  But if you went by this film, you'd think he had few friends and nobody to count on but his wife Linda.Ashley Judd is completely miscast as the wealthy divorcee who connects with Porter.  She has no chemistry with Kline or anyone else in the film, and is too young for the part.Kline himself is too old to play the young Porter and the ridiculously bad make-up used to make him the "old Porter" makes this viewer wish they had cast 2 actors.Kline certainly has the right energy and vivacity to play a convincing Porter, but he needs a good script and a clever director and talented co-stars..all of which he was lacking in this sad excuse for a biopic.Don't even get me started on the simply murderous versions of some of Porter's most wonderful songs, massacred by the modernized orchestrations and deliveries of the likes of Sheryl Crow (!!! Her take on "Begin the Beguine" is the worst cover of a Porter song I've ever heard--it doesn't even sound like the same song!), Elvis Costello, and other minor artists that don't deserve the few seconds given to them on screen.Such a wasted opportunity to make a wonderful story for the screen about one of our greatest composers.  Sad on all accounts.If you want a better view of Porter's life and his music, I recommend the musical RED, HOT & COLE, a wonderful show that was written in the late 70s and was produced in LA and Richmond (never got to Broadway), but that uses Porters songs and the setting of several of his "swell parties", to tell his life story much more interestingly than this film could ever hope to do.

reviewText: Most critics panned it; I loved this film. Yes, Cole Porter's life as shown is a series of snapshots interspersed with many of the song hits he wrote. That shouldn't bother anyone, especially if you've seen that old white-washed version with Cary Grant and Alexis Smith. In one scene Porter (Kevin Kline), and Linda Lee (Ashley Judd)--his wife--sit in a movie theater watching that film. Smith looked ridiculous running over to Porter. It was too melodramatic and just doesn't hold up anymore; in fact, it was quite funny.The film begins with Porter, very old, ill and weary, sitting alone at a piano. A man--like the ghost of Christmas Past--walks in and takes him back through snapshot scenes of Porter's life. And what a life! (My only criticism is about the time Porter lived abroad/in Paris. The 20/30's were such a wild and exciting time for the rich. They felt they could do anything and usually did. There was a good attempt at showing us this e.g., a tamed 'wild' costume party but you really never got a sense of how fun and decadent it really was.When I heard that Alanis Morissette and Sheryl Crow were cast to sing in the film, I thought,'what are they doing there?! Associating Porter's work with the past was something I couldn't get away from. I expected crooners and female replicas of various 40's band singers. However, when I saw the film, I was astonished at how well a contemporary spin on the past works. Morissette and Crow were perfect casting choices. I suppose however that's why songs become standards; they can easily be sung by anyone during any one generation and sound wonderful.The relationship between Lee and Porter was a marriage of convenience that few people could really understand. I've known people like this and they love each other as passionately as the best of lovers, even if they seldom do in a physical way. A very good friendship can be a powerful anchor.Later in the film, Lee becomes ill and these are Judd's best scenes. She may not have pulled off the wealthy sophisticate, but she definitely comes across when the going gets tough. (Judd could be cast in a remake of Fitzgerald's 'Tender Is The Night'. The original version with Jennifer Jones was good but Jones was too old for the part.)Kline is exceptionally good. He portrays Porter as sophisticated, intelligent, so talented that he could come up with melodies and lyrics on the spot, jaded as heard in his song, 'Love For Sale', angry, sad, trivial and child-like and brutally honest about himself.(One word about a certain production number. A lead singer performs exactly like Ethel Merman. She looks like her, sings like her and even moves like her. Just wonderful! I don't know her name.)At the end of the film, all of Porter's past friends and lovers and his wife Linda Lee, step off stage and greet Porter as he sits in the audience beaming with delight at their presence. They're his life story come to life for the last time.In the end though, get out your hankies because you will use them. I was very upset. Maybe if I were 20 or 30 I wouldn't have felt that way but the end of this film makes an older person think about his mortality and what everything in his life meant. Here, you have a man who had everything yet in the end was alone, at his insistance. Regardless, it makes you think if anything has value, even relationships, for in the end wealth, the good times and all the past fun and craziness mean nothing; it was terrifying. What was it all for? For Porter at least, it was for a legacy of songs that will be remembered and sung for generatins to come. That's not too bad is it?

reviewText: Somehow, everyone connected with this film managed to make a biopic about Cole Porter, one of the 20th century's greatest songwriters ("Anything Goes," "You're the Top," "Just One of Those Things," "In the Still of the Night"), into a hackneyed, boring, and overly sentimental cinematic equivalent of boiled tripe. The film focuses too much on his closeted struggles and romances with women, but to reduce Porter to this treatment is silly and salacious. Kevin Kline comes off as so blase as an aged Porter reminiscing about his life and legendary career, and it was difficult to empathize with someone so worldweary, emotionally distant, and lacking in any depth of feeling for the people he hurt throughout his life. I realize that being an artist involves a lot of time spent in isolation, perfecting one's artwork, but still, I would have preferred to see more of Porter's struggles as an artist (although he came from a wealthy Episcopalian family in Indiana, and was considered to be a millionaire dilettante by many songwriters on Broadway and Tin Pan Alley). I also would have liked to see more insight into his creative process instead of this "greatest hits" paean that, unfortunately, seems intent on killing off any younger viewer's budding interest in the man and his work. He wrote some of his best songs when trying to "write Jewish," as he reportedly explained to Richard Rodgers, in trying to imitate such successful songwriters as Irving Berlin, George Gershwin, and Rodgers. This film was a squandered opportunity.
summary: Huge disservice to Porter -- too much emphasize on his closeted struggles

reviewText: Usually my reviews are long and detailed, but this film doesn't rate this.  It varies wildly between brilliance and utter banality.  It seems to want to be both modern and an old-fashioned "just the lines, please" biography of the type that is actually derided in this movie, the earlier fictionalized Porter biography starring Cary Grant.  There are a couple of mysteries the audience is left with, mainly because so many of the characters seem to be fictionalized: such as the blond ballet dancer whom we see is Porter's male lover while courting and marrying Linda.  (No explicit sex or nudity in this film; merely some non-passionate kissing both male-female and male-male.)  And also John Barrowman's "Jack," who is probably another imaginary or composite character.  However, Barrowman is actually one of the bright spots of the film.  The scene where Kline as Porter coaches him (an established musical star in real life) in how to sing NIGHT AND DAY is a classic, especially since it is also the only scene where Kline is able to sing as Kline (he's sung Gilbert and Sullivan on Broadway (THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE) and therefore had to tone down his own vocal prowess to play non-singer Porter, who has many numbers in the film).  And though the rest of the staging of the musical numbers, with the exception of ANYTHING GOES, is anything but old-fashioned, Barrowman's singing of NIGHT AND DAY could have been lifted from a time capsule, the manner and staging stiff and unbelievable, but true to the time.  The casting of Judd as Linda is interesting; she physically inhabits the role and is a wonderful actress, even though criticism is she is younger than Kline whereas the real Linda was older than Porter.  Only if you know this fact, however, would the casting of Judd as Linda bother you.  In fact, while watching the film, since Judd has such a physical similarity to Kline's real-life wife, who is probably older than Judd, it made me wonder why Phoebe Cates wasn't cast as Linda.  Then, there might have been real chemistry between the two leads, which is lacking in the Judd-Kline pairing.  They are two pros working together, but nothing special here.  Regarding the musical numbers, some are excellent on their own, worthy music videos, but much of the time is spent by the audience playing spot-the-singer, which takes one out of the film for distressingly long periods of time, smacking the viewer in the face with reality when they need to be immersed in the story unfolding on-screen, not in how so-and-so looks in that dress and hairstyle or Gee, you mean they can actually SING?  How about that.

reviewText: You get two great things about 'De-Lovely'; one is of course Cole Porter songs sung by the cast and cameo singers, and the other is fine performance from Kevin Kline as Porter.  As he says in this film, Kevin Kline 'can survive anything.'  Even this clithed biopic.At least, as a biopic, 'De-Lovely' is more honest than the  preceeding one 'Night and Day' made in 1946.  The new one, describing the frivolous entertainers' world with meticulously created costumes (by G. Armani), doesn't hesitate to touch the sexual matters more explicitly, and Porter's unique relations with Linda Porter (Ashley Judd) are surely shown.And Kevin Kline again proves that he is such a gifted actor, easily exuding the charms of Porter himself in a convincing manner.  Though I don't know whether his playing Porter all through his life (from young to aged) is a good idea, Kline tackles it with special make-ups, and the results are fairly good (though the same cannot be said about Ashley Judd, who looks buried in unnatural prosthetics).But Irwin Winkler's heavy-handed directions are awfully damaging while the predestrian script does not add up to much.  When you see Jonathan Pryce, who 'directs' the stage (in some dark and dingy theater) on which the fictional life of Porter is played, and Kevin Kline's glum and grim Porter watches it, we know this contrivance is unnecessary.  And the film fails to make us understand why Linda is so attracted to Cole.  If you do, that's because you are watching Kevin Kline, not Porter, as such a charming fellow.The brightest spots are its songs.  I don't write down all the titles performed, but the musicians who gathered for this film  are all great.  They include Elvis Costello, Natalie Cole, Sheryl Crow, Mario Frangoulis, Lara Fabian, Vivian Green, Alanis Morissette, Mick Hucknall, Robbie Williams, Lemar, and Diana Krall.You don't find special things about Porter himself in 'De-Lovely.'  But the music is all superb, and why not? it's Cole Porter.  See, or hear this one for its music, and then you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: Funny that "De-Lovely" has the gall to be snide toward the 1946 film "Night and Day," when it suffers from every single one of that film's problems: miscast, timid, inaccurate, boring, and a numbingly wasted opportunity to be great.Can you watch this film and have any opinion about Porter, or Monty Woolley, or Gerald and Sara Murphy?  I never met any of them, but there is no way they were witless nothings.  That's what everyone in this movie is...a nothing.  Clearly, they didn't want to offend anyone by showing what Cole and Monty's sexual escapades were really like, or what kind of personality would dream up the naughtiness of a lyric like "I've got you under my skin" and "you're the top."The Hollywood section was mystifying.  What movie with a mountie and an indian princess are they representing?  Was that supposed to be "Rose Marie"?  Wasn't "Rosalie" the film where Porter wrote a horrible title song that Louis B. Mayer actually liked?Didn't Fred Astaire introduce "Night and Day" in the stage production "The Gay Divorce", and not Cole's lover? (who the hell is "Jack"?)  The movie doesn't even mention the title of the show, or give any idea when any of this is taking place.In other words, this is a biopic designed for people who have heard some Porter songs but know nothing about him.  No, it doesn't need to be a 100% accurate catalog of his life, but come ON...show the audience a little respect and try to at least get the historical details straight--give your movie some kind of credibility.They even pulled in a bunch of contemporary artists (Robbie Williams, Diana Krall), and for the most part don't let them complete entire numbers.  What is going on with that arrangement of "Begin the Beguine" by Sheryl Crow?  Would't it have been better to have these stars sing these songs as they were arranged, and not re-interpret them?And the bookending segments with Jonathan Pryce...good Lord.  What is this--A Christmas Carol?  Maybe they were trying for a little "All That Jazz"-type plotting.  Good luck with that.  That movie had guts and wasn't afraid to be ugly...this movie is absolute decorous nonsense.I wouldn't be so hard on this movie if it hadn't tried to pass itself off as somehow correcting the mistake of the movie "Night and Day"...this movie is JUST as flawed.One redeeming quality: everyone I saw the movie with went out looking for Cole Porter songs to download off the internet.  So, lets be thankful even crappy musicals like this can keep classic songs alive.Maybe one day Scorsese will make his promised film about Gershwin, and we'll see how good a composer biopic can be.

reviewText: Is 'De-Lovely' a musical movie or a film surging with the gloriousness of Cole Porter's tunes?  Well, it is both, but the latter aspect far out-weighs the former, and thank God for that.  During the film you can tell how standard it would have been if it had contained endless amounts of recurring ensemble numbers and waltzes in Parisian gardens.  Luckily, director Irwin Winkler managed to collect the cream of the modern singing crop and sprinkle them over this trifle of a bio-pic, all singing the best of Porter's collection.  Unfortunately, that is the film's strongest quality (along with some redeemably creative editing).  The music endears, and you find yourself snapping along to its resonance in your memory as the credits begin to roll and you begin to walk right out of that theater.  But what you don't remember well are the problematic performances and Jonathan Pryce's Gabe, a man irritatingly interviewing an old Cole Porter (Kevin Kline) as they watch his life and relationship with wife Linda Porter (Ashely Judd) play out in the form of a musical.  And although the film attempts to be unconventional in its portrayal of love, it doesn't seem to have focus in its execution of Linda and Cole's situation in which Cole is gay and Linda doesn't seem to mind.  What could have been an interestingly creative portrait of a marriage that survived its potentially dangerous dysfunction ended up losing sight of its goals half-way through, in turn giving us something almost completely disposable.  Buy the soundtrack, not the tickets.

reviewText: "De-Lovely" uses some of the greatest love songs ever written to serve as the connecting link to the biography of the man who wrote them, Cole Porter.  The approach of director Irwin Winkler works as we see intelligent segues from Porter, composing in whatever setting, to ultimate execution on stage.  A host of current popular stars such as Sheryl Crow, Natalie Cole and Alanis Morissette, to name but a few, are called on to provide the numbers with their ultimate flourish after Porter has laid the necessary groundwork.Kevin Kline portrays the songwriter, who came from a small Indiana town but was a scion to great wealth.  In Paris he meets and falls in love with Ashley Judd, who is described as "the most beautiful divorcee" in that dashing city of light.  She is actually a shade short of divorce when she meets the fun loving songwriter, and one tense and brief scene develops involving the new lovebirds and the alcoholic, wife-beating husband she is shedding.A major element of concern for Judd as wife to a man with constant champagne wishes and caviar dreams and a pocketbook to match is that he focus enough energy to fully develop his talents.  Kline comments that the lavish villa they occupy in romantic Venice was once occupied by Robert Browning, who did far more writing there but had a lot less fun than the songwriter.  At one point Irving Berlin pays court, telling Porter how impressed he is with his talent.Coaxing by Mrs. Porter and a favorable tribute from Berlin prompts Broadway to beckon the songwriter's call.  He disciplines himself satisfactorily to go there and take New York by storm with his music.The subject of Porter's bisexuality is handled tastefully.  Judd never attempts to change him, but chastises him when he fails to be discrete.  Visits to a gay nightclub result in both Judd and Kline being blackmailed by one enterprising opportunist with a design on starting a theatrical agency.  The Porters become the blackmailer's designated financial angels.Porter explains to Judd and anyone close to him who wants to know that he is truly the sum of his various disparate parts.  While Judd can give him a certain type of love, he requires another type of affection from homosexual encounters.  If he sometimes seems to stray too far from work in pursuit of fun, he emphatically states that he needs to be in the correct mood to successfully create.At one point Judd is prepared to leave Kline, but when he is injured falling from a horse and has to have his legs amputated she remains with him and serves as his pillar of strength.  The gesture is fully returned.  When Judd, an inveterate smoker, becomes terminally ill from lung cancer he is there to be her needed Rock of Gibraltar.The music alone is enough to make viewing the film worthwhile, but there is so much more, excellent choreography and depth of characterization within the framework of superb music.  In addition to the song that comprises the film's title, "De-Lovely", others greats from the Porter bountiful repertoire are also included, such enduring classics as "Night and Day", which was the title of the dramatic film version of Porter's life starring Cary Grant and Alexis Smith, as well as "In the Still of the Night" and "You'd be so Easy to Love" while at the film's conclusion a rousing rendition of "Blow Gabriel Blow" is appropriately presented.Jonathan Pryce, billed as Gabe and appropriately the angel Gabriel, puts Porter through his paces from a different dimension.  The songwriter has an opportunity to see his fascinating life pass in review, one beset by travel, adventure, luxury and, above all, love and song.

reviewText: Call me old-fashioned, but I think there's something wrong with a movie that spends more time dealing with the sexual preference of a great composer than it does with his music. And I think it's terribly misleading to hype said film as an old-style Hollywood musical.DE-LOVELY, which covers the life and career of Cole Porter, is definitely a film worth seeing. It takes great care in presenting the curious and loving marriage between Porter (well-played by Kevin Kline) and his wife Linda (Ashley Judd, in another impressive performance), who, despite her husband's homosexuality, remained a devoted spouse. The fact that DE-LOVELY openly deals with his sexuality doesn't bother me in the slightest. What does bother me is that the magnificent Porter song catalogue is frittered away. Contemporary pop singers Alanis Morissette, Sheryl Crow, Elvis Costello, Diana Krall, and Natalie Cole turn up to warble such Porter standards as "Let's Do It," "It Was Just One of Those Things," "Begin the Beguine," "Anything Goes," and "Let's Misbehave," yet nearly all these renditions are whittled down to fragments. Very few of the songs are presented intact. What's the point of having Robbie Williams sing "It's De-Lovely"-the title song, no less!-if you're not going to allow the audience to hear the entire thing? Why document Porter's sexual escapades in detail then give short shrift to his true legacy? And why should anyone who's already paid to see the movie have to purchase the soundtrack in order to hear the whole score? (Strangely, two of the numbers presented in their complete form are, in my opinion, two of Porter's lesser efforts: "Be a Clown" and "Well, Did You Evah?")Striving for truth and accuracy in a Hollywood movie biography is an ultimately pointless undertaking. THE JOLSON STORY (1946) was a hugely entertaining biopic. Would it have been more entertaining if Al Jolson had been portrayed as the ruthless egomaniac he reportedly was in real life, rather than the kindhearted soul depicted in the film? I think not. If we're searching for accuracy, why not get Steve Buscemi to play Cole Porter, since he looks more like Porter than Kevin Kline does. Another fact: Linda was several years older than Cole, hardly the fresh-faced young character played by Ashley Judd. As a result, the true dynamics of their real-life relationship is never fully delved into.In NIGHT AND DAY (1946), an earlier Cole Porter biopic, Cary Grant played the composer in a sanitized version of his life story. The watered-down screenplay may not have been accurate, but the studio (Warner Brothers) wasn't concerned about it; they just let those wonderful Cole Porter songs play out in all their glory. At least they got that part right.Still, I'm awarding DE-LOVELY three stars, primarily on the strength of the lead performances. The pity is that, with the proper presentation of the music, it could have been a five-star effort.
